''[[The World Is What It Is]]'', an authorized biography of [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] prize winning author [[V.S Naipaul]] was published in 2008. In the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', [[Ian Buruma]] conferred French as the inventor of a new genre, âthe confessional biographer.â<ref>[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22062 The Lessons of the Master] The New York Review of Books. November 20, 2008.</ref> The book was selected by the editors of ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' as one of the â10 Best books of 2008.â<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/books/review/10Best-t.html?_r=2 The ten best books of 2008] The New York Times. December 3, 2008.</ref> In 2008, ''[[The World Is What It Is]]'' was awarded the [[National Book Critics Circle Award]]<ref>[http://bookcritics.org/awards Winners of the National Book Critics Circle Award]</ref> in America, and was also short listed for the [[Samuel Johnson]] Prize.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/books/features/samueljohnson/shortlist.shtml List of Winners of the Samuel Johnson Prize]</ref> French was also awarded the [[Hawthornden Prize]] in 2009 for the book.<ref>[http://www.panmacmillan.com/News/displayPage.asp?PageTitle=Patrick%20French%20awarded%20literary%20prize Patrick French awarded Literary prize]</ref>
''[[The World Is What It Is]]'', an authorized biography of [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] prize winning author [[V.S Naipaul]] was published in 2008. In the ''[[New York Review of Books]]'', [[Ian Buruma]] conferred French as the inventor of a new genre, âthe confessional biographer.â<ref>[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22062 The Lessons of the Master] The New York Review of Books. November 20, 2008.</ref> The book was selected by the editors of ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' as one of the â10 Best books of 2008.â<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/books/review/10Best-t.html?_r=2 The ten best books of 2008] The New York Times. December 3, 2008.</ref> In 2008, ''[[The World Is What It Is]]'' was awarded the [[National Book Critics Circle Award]]<ref>[http://bookcritics.org/awards Winners of the National Book Critics Circle Award]</ref> in America, and was also short listed for the [[Samuel Johnson]] Prize.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/books/features/samueljohnson/shortlist.shtml List of Winners of the Samuel Johnson Prize]</ref> French was also awarded the [[Hawthornden Prize]] in 2009 for the book.<ref>[http://www.panmacmillan.com/News/displayPage.asp?PageTitle=Patrick%20French%20awarded%20literary%20prize Patrick French awarded Literary prize]</ref>
â
In 2010, Patrick released his book 'India: A Portrait'. He calls it 'an intimate biogrpahy of 1.2 billion people'. The book is a narrative of the social and economic revolutions that are transforming India. As part of the book release, he has also started an India focused website called [http://www.theindiasite.com/ The India Site.<ref> http://www.theindiasite.com/india-a-portrait/ </ref>
+
In 2010, Patrick released his book 'India: A Portrait'. He calls it 'an intimate biogrpahy of 1.2 billion people'. The book is a narrative of the social and economic revolutions that are transforming India. As part of the book release, he has also started an India focused website called The India Site.<ref> http://www.theindiasite.com/india-a-portrait/ </ref>
